As a long-time Pennsylvania voter, I just want to point out that it's not like we never had to identify ourselves before. We have always had to present a photo ID when we first registered, and proof of change of address if we move and change polling places. This new law just makes the acceptable ID very stringent. Seniors who registered decades ago and have been voting in the same polling place for all that time may be greeted by their first name by poll workers and then told sorry, no photo ID, no vote. The law requires a raised seal birth certificate, a Social Security card (not enough to just know your number) and two proofs of current address, not to vote, mind you, but to get the ID to take to the polling place. And if you're a woman, you also have to present a marriage certificate as proof of name change, and everything better match. The opportunities for abuse by election and DMV workers are huge.

Sorry, but the ad was dishonest. They should have said "lawyer specializing in software licensing, who married an heiress." But I guess you feel that wasn't enough to work with.

Bruce -

Sorry, but the ad claiming he was a "regular guy" was even more "dishonest" by that standard. Campaign hyperbole is what it is. It is common because it gets people's attention in a hyperbolic media environment.

But this article is more about Wall Street than it is campaign hyperbole..

"Mr. Rehberg also voted against the bank bailout. So instead of focusing on TARP, ads pummel Mr. Rehberg for his longtime support for privatizing Social Security — in other words, putting retirement funds in the hands of Wall Street money managers."

So apparently making legitimate points about an opponent position is also off limits if they merely imply criticism of wall street? What appears flimsy is this and other examples provided. It appears not only are some of these candidates in Wall Street's pocket, but so is the author of this diatribe.

What is more misleading, the ads connecting Rothfus to one of his clients or his attempt to portray himself as "just a regular guy"? This may surprise the author and his Wall street buddies, but most people don't consider people who have $5-$13 million in the bank "regular guys". And they don't consider making $125,000 a "modest" income.

If Wall Street weren't in just disrepute right now, Rothfus would be crowing about his experience doing work for a major Wall Street bank. There is lots of hyperbole on all sides of campaigns. There is really nothing out of the ordinary here. What appears to make it newsworthy is the target is a powerful special interest with very thin skin.

Totally agree with this comment.  I had to participate in a 'team building' event at work last year.  I suggested an activity that didn't revolve around drinking, but was vetoed by the other people (men) on the project.  We went to a ball game and then to a bar; I had two beers while they got wasted.  Inappropriate sexual comments were made, but *I* was the one considered 'not a team player' the next morning when I was annoyed that the guys wanted to start the work day late.  One of them threw up in the bathroom at the office.  Go team.

It is a good idea to let someone know you are not drinking but even so-called non-alcoholic beer has some small amount of alcohol so those in recovery often will not drink it. Much better to order yourself the club soda or seltzer with a lime and stirrer and let others think you have a mixed drink. In fact, it is often suggested to those in recovery that they have a non-alcoholic carbonated drink in hand so they won't be tempted by the alcoholic one.

As for the idea that others suggested of having an alcoholic drink sitting in front of you, while not drinking it: this may be tempting for some in recovery--even those with long-term sobriety. But, better that they take whatever precautions they need to than subject themselves and others to the devastation that is alcoholism. And that wonderful job? It may well disappear if one's drinking recurs, never mind the misguided pressure to drink to be one of the guys or girls and to develop the relationships needed for business.

Yes, MJ, and isn't that awful?  Our society knows so little about the dangers of drinking for some and the normalcy of not wanting to drink for others.  It is a tragedy that one's career can realistically be affected by whether one imbibes and it is also a tragedy that those who cannot, or do not want, to drink feel pressured to do so even when such pressure may not exist.

Hate, hate, hate the whole alcohol industry.  I was with my boyfriend for 2 years before I found out he was in recovery.  He is in sales, very masculine, used to play pro sports. So he seems to get by with not drinking on charisma.  However, anyone who has lived through relapses of a loved one can only feel contempt for these ignoramus men -- it's in the same form that professional women face in a man's work world -- the blankety blank men's club.  i really would like to knock their heads together and that includes the nagging waiter who, unless you get in his face and say you are in AA -- will simply not stop PUSHING alcohol.

I generally enjoy a good drink or two when i'm out with colleagues.  However, there are times when I don't feel like drinking and don't want to explain myself to my peers.  I'll often ask for ice-tea in a scotch glass and 'nurse" it accordingly.  I've never had an issue, and many bartenders seem to understand the deal.
